questions.question_text_1: A company produces a car in two locations “A” and “B” using the same manufacturing process. A total of 20 cars in each location were taken and the number of defects in each car was computed. It has been established that the maximum number of defects per car is 5. Given this data in Table-1, answer the given sub-questions.
questions.question_text_2: A company produces a car in two locations “A” and “B” using the same manufacturing process. A total of 20 cars in each location were taken and the number of defects in each car was computed. It has been established that the maximum number of defects per car is 5. Given this data in Table-1, answer the given sub-questions.

It has been established that the maximum number of defects per car is 5. Given this data in Table-1, answer the given sub-questions.

questions.question_text_1: If the focus is on seeing the distribution of defects (presented in Table-1) across the two locations, then which among the following graphs will be best suited? (Note: While choosing an answer to this question, please do not worry about colour reproduction or other aesthetics. Make a choice only based on the concepts of visualization theory)

questions.question_text_1: If the aim is to determine if the defect occurrence is independent of location, then how many cars would you expect to have “4” defects in Location A? (Round your answer to two decimal places. Eg: If your answer is 10.256, then round it to 10.26)

questions.question_text_1: Chef Jeff is curious to see about his LPG gas connection. He is of the opinion that gas consumption depends on the type of food (“baked items” or “fried items”) he prepares. Hence, over the past month, he has monitored his gas consumption for various items he has prepared (please do not worry about how the data is generated, it is not in the scope of the question). Using this data, Chef Jeff has built several regression models (Model-1, Model-2 and Model-3) which are specified below. He is happy with a 95% Confidence level. Given this information, answer the given subquestions. (Note: For all the sub-questions, round your answer to two decimal places. Eg: If your answer is 10.256, then round it to 10.26)

Using this data, Chef Jeff has built several regression models (Model-1, Model-2 and Model-3) which are specified below. He is happy with a 95% Confidence level. Given this information, answer the given subquestions. (Note: For all the sub-questions, round your answer to two decimal places. Eg: If your answer is 10.256, then round it to 10.26)

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Diploma in Business Analytics (Computer-Based Exam)**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Descriptive Statistics & Data Visualization**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Skewness**:
  - **Negative Skewness**: Mode > Median > Mean.
  - **Positive Skewness**: Mean > Median > Mode.
  - **Symmetric Distribution**: Mean = Median = Mode.

- **Data Visualization**:
  - **Bar Charts**: Best for comparing categorical data (e.g., defects across locations).
  - **Line Graphs**: Best for trends over time.
  - **Pie Charts**: Best for proportional data.
  - **Histograms**: Best for distribution of continuous data.

### **Key Equations:**
- **Skewness Coefficient (Pearson’s)**:
  \[
  \text{Skewness} = \frac{3(\text{Mean} - \text{Median})}{\text{Standard Deviation}}
  \]

### **Mermaid Graph: Data Visualization Choices**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Data Type] --> B[Categorical]
    A --> C[Numerical]
    B --> D[Bar Chart]
    B --> E[Pie Chart]
    C --> F[Histogram]
    C --> G[Line Graph]
    C --> H[Scatter Plot]
```

---

## **2. Hypothesis Testing (Chi-Square Test for Independence)**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Chi-Square Test**:
  - Tests if two categorical variables are independent.
  - **Expected Frequency**:
    \[
    E_{ij} = \frac{(\text{Row Total}_i) \times (\text{Column Total}_j)}{\text{Grand Total}}
    \]
  - **Test Statistic**:
    \[
    \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_{ij} - E_{ij})^2}{E_{ij}}
    \]
  - **Degrees of Freedom (df)**:
    \[
    df = (\text{rows} - 1) \times (\text{columns} - 1)
    \]

### **Key Steps:**
1. Calculate expected frequencies.
2. Compute the chi-square statistic.
3. Compare with critical value (from chi-square table) or p-value.

### **Mermaid Graph: Chi-Square Test Workflow**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Collect Observed Frequencies] --> B[Calculate Expected Frequencies]
    B --> C[Compute Chi-Square Statistic]
    C --> D[Determine Degrees of Freedom]
    D --> E[Compare with Critical Value]
    E --> F[Reject/Fail to Reject Null Hypothesis]
```

---

## **3. Poisson Distribution & Goodness-of-Fit Test**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Poisson Distribution**:
  - Models count data (e.g., defects per car).
  - **Probability Mass Function (PMF)**:
    \[
    P(X = k) = \frac{e^{-\lambda} \lambda^k}{k!}
    \]
  - **Mean & Variance**: Both equal to \(\lambda\).

- **Goodness-of-Fit Test**:
  - Tests if observed data fits a theoretical distribution (e.g., Poisson).
  - Uses chi-square statistic.

### **Key Equations:**
- **Lambda (\(\lambda\)) Estimation**:
  \[
  \lambda = \text{Sample Mean}
  \]
- **Chi-Square Test Statistic**:
  \[
  \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
  \]

### **Mermaid Graph: Poisson Goodness-of-Fit Test**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Collect Defect Data] --> B[Calculate Sample Mean λ]
    B --> C[Compute Expected Frequencies]
    C --> D[Calculate Chi-Square Statistic]
    D --> E[Compare with Critical Value]
```

---

## **4. Linear Regression & Multicollinearity**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Simple Linear Regression**:
  - **Model**: \( Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \epsilon \)
  - **Coefficients**: Interpreted as the change in \(Y\) per unit change in \(X\).
  - **R-Squared (\(R^2\))**: Proportion of variance in \(Y\) explained by \(X\).

- **Multicollinearity**:
  - Occurs when predictor variables are highly correlated.
  - **Detection**:
    - High **Variance Inflation Factor (VIF)** (>5 or 10).
    - Correlation matrix between predictors.
  - **Effect**: Unstable coefficient estimates.

- **ANOVA Table**:
  - **F-Statistic**: Tests overall significance of the model.
  - **p-value**: If < 0.05, the model is significant.

### **Key Equations:**
- **Regression Coefficients**:
  \[
  \beta_1 = \frac{\sum (X_i - \bar{X})(Y_i - \bar{Y})}{\sum (X_i - \bar{X})^2}
  \]
- **R-Squared**:
  \[
  R^2 = 1 - \frac{SS_{\text{res}}}{SS_{\text{tot}}}
  \]
- **F-Statistic**:
  \[
  F = \frac{MS_{\text{reg}}}{MS_{\text{res}}}
  \]

### **Mermaid Graph: Regression Analysis Workflow**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Collect Data] --> B[Fit Regression Model]
    B --> C[Check R-Squared & p-values]
    C --> D[Test for Multicollinearity]
    D --> E[Interpret Coefficients]
```

---

## **5. Elasticity & Demand Modeling**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Price Elasticity of Demand (PED)**:
  - Measures responsiveness of demand to price changes.
  - **Formula**:
    \[
    \text{PED} = \frac{\% \Change \text{ in Quantity Demanded}}{\% \Change \text{ in Price}}
    \]
  - **Interpretation**:
    - \(|PED| > 1\): Elastic (demand sensitive to price).
    - \(|PED| < 1\): Inelastic (demand insensitive to price).

- **Constant Elasticity Model**:
  - \( Q = kP^\epsilon \), where \(\epsilon\) is elasticity.

### **Key Equations:**
- **Log-Log Model (for estimating elasticity)**:
  \[
  \ln(Q) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \ln(P)
  \]
  (Here, \(\beta_1 = \text{Elasticity}\))

### **Mermaid Graph: Demand Elasticity**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Collect Price & Demand Data] --> B[Plot Demand Curve]
    B --> C[Estimate Elasticity]
    C --> D[Interpret Elasticity]
```

---

## **6. Linear Programming & Duality**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Primal & Dual Problems**:
  - **Primal**: Minimization problem with constraints.
  - **Dual**: Maximization problem derived from primal.
  - **Relationship**:
    - Number of dual variables = Number of primal constraints.
    - Optimal values of primal and dual are equal (Strong Duality).

- **Decision Variables**:
  - Variables in the objective function.

- **Slack/Surplus Variables**:
  - Added to inequalities to convert them to equalities.

### **Key Equations:**
- **Dual Problem Formation**:
  - If primal is:
    \[
    \text{Minimize } c^T x \text{ subject to } Ax \geq b, x \geq 0
    \]
  - Dual is:
    \[
    \text{Maximize } b^T y \text{ subject to } A^T y \leq c, y \geq 0
    \]

### **Mermaid Graph: Primal-Dual Relationship**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Primal Problem] -->|Constraints| B[Dual Variables]
    A -->|Objective| C[Dual Objective]
    B --> D[Dual Problem]
    C --> D
```

---

## **7. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Efficiency Measurement**:
  - Compares **Decision-Making Units (DMUs)** based on inputs/outputs.
  - **Efficient Frontier**: DMUs that are technically efficient.

- **DEA Models**:
  - **CCR Model (Charnes, Cooper, Rhodes)**:
    - Constant Returns to Scale (CRS).
  - **BCC Model (Banker, Charnes, Cooper)**:
    - Variable Returns to Scale (VRS).

- **Efficiency Score**:
  - \(0 \leq \text{Efficiency} \leq 1\) (1 = fully efficient).

### **Key Equations:**
- **DEA Efficiency Score**:
  \[
  \text{Maximize } E_k = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^M y_j O_{jk}}{\sum_{i=1}^N x_i I_{ik}}
  \]
  Subject to similar ratios for all DMUs \(\leq 1\).

### **Mermaid Graph: DEA Efficiency Evaluation**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Select DMUs] --> B[Define Inputs/Outputs]
    B --> C[Solve DEA Model]
    C --> D[Identify Efficient DMUs]
    D --> E[Benchmark Inefficient DMUs]
```

---

## **8. Conjoint Analysis**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Preference Modeling**:
  - Decomposes customer preferences into attribute-level utilities.
- **Pairwise Comparisons**:
  - Customers compare two products at a time.
  - **Number of Pairs**: For \(n\) products, pairs = \(\binom{n}{2} = \frac{n(n-1)}{2}\).
- **Optimization Approach**:
  - Used when attributes are continuous.

### **Key Equations:**
- **Utility Function**:
  \[
  U = \sum_{i=1}^k \beta_i X_i
  \]
  (where \(X_i\) = attribute levels, \(\beta_i\) = part-worth utilities)

### **Mermaid Graph: Conjoint Analysis Process**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Define Attributes & Levels] --> B[Create Product Profiles]
    B --> C[Collect Pairwise Preferences]
    C --> D[Estimate Part-Worth Utilities]
    D --> E[Predict Customer Choices]
```

---

## **9. Confusion Matrix & Model Evaluation**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Confusion Matrix**:
  |                   | Actual Negative | Actual Positive |
  |-------------------|-----------------|-----------------|
  | **Predict Negative** | True Negative (TN) | False Negative (FN) |
  | **Predict Positive** | False Positive (FP) | True Positive (TP) |

- **Metrics**:
  - **Accuracy**:
    \[
    \text{Accuracy} = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN}
    \]
  - **Precision (Positive Class)**:
    \[
    \text{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP + FP}
    \]
  - **Recall (Sensitivity)**:
    \[
    \text{Recall} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN}
    \]
  - **F1-Score**:
    \[
    F1 = 2 \times \frac{\text{Precision} \times \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}}
    \]

### **Mermaid Graph: Model Evaluation Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Confusion Matrix] --> B[Calculate Accuracy]
    A --> C[Calculate Precision]
    A --> D[Calculate Recall]
    B --> E[Overall Performance]
    C --> F[Positive Class Performance]
    D --> F
```

---

## **10. Efficiency Frontiers & Benchmarking**
### **Core Topics:**
- **Economic Frontier**:
  - Represents the maximum output achievable for given inputs.
- **Inefficient Units**:
  - Lie below the frontier (can improve output without increasing inputs).
- **Benchmarking**:
  - Compare DMUs to the frontier to identify inefficiencies.

### **Mermaid Graph: Efficiency Frontier**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Plot DMUs] --> B[Identify Frontier]
    B --> C[Measure Distance from Frontier]
    C --> D[Classify as Efficient/Inefficient]
```

---

## **Summary of Key Formulas**
| **Topic**               | **Key Formula**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Skewness                | \(\text{Skewness} = \frac{3(\text{Mean} - \text{Median})}{\text{SD}}\)          |
| Chi-Square Test         | \(\chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O - E)^2}{E}\)                                          |
| Poisson PMF             | \(P(X=k) = \frac{e^{-\lambda} \lambda^k}{k!}\)                                |
| Linear Regression       | \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \epsilon\)                                        |
| Elasticity              | \(\text{PED} = \frac{\% \Delta Q}{\% \Delta P}\)                              |
| DEA Efficiency          | \(E_k = \frac{\sum y_j O_{jk}}{\sum x_i I_{ik}}\)                              |
| Confusion Matrix Metrics| Accuracy = \(\frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN}\)                                |
